elements.content: Four new uranyl triphosphonates, namely, [N­(CH4)4]­[UO2(H3L)]­[H2O] (1), [(UO2)1.5(H3L)­(H2O)1.5]­[H2O] (2), [NBu4]­[(UO2)3.5­(H2L)2]­[(H2O)4.5] (3), and [(UO2)1.5(H3L)­(H2O)2.5]­[(H2O)2.5] (4), where H6L = benzene-1,3,5-triyltris­(methylene)­triphosphonic acid, were obtained from a triphosphonate ligand in the presence of different quaternary ammonium cations. The structural characterization revealed that the introduction of quaternary ammonium cation had a major impact on the structure formation of uranyl phosphonates. Compound 1 possesses a three-dimensional anionic framework structure. Tetramethylammonium cations are accommodated in the channels, serving as counterions and structure directing agents. Compound 2 also displays a three-dimensional framework structure but is neutral, because the tetrapropylammonium cations are not involved in the crystal structure. Compound 3 has an intercalation structure; between the layers are the tetrabutylammonium cations, balancing the charge and strengthening the supramolecular structure with C–H···O interactions. No obvious uptake of N2 and CO2 could be observed for compound 2 due to the shrinkage of the framework and structural transformation. Compound 2 undergoes single-crystal to single-crystal transformation under vacuum, leading to the formation of compound 4, which possesses a two-dimensional layer structure. The photophysical properties of these compounds were also investigated.

The structural characterization revealed that the introduction of quaternary ammonium cation had a major impact on the structure formation of uranyl phosphonates. Compound 1 possesses a three-dimensional anionic framework structure. Tetramethylammonium cations are accommodated in the channels, serving as counterions and structure directing agents. Compound 2 also displays a three-dimensional framework structure but is neutral, because the tetrapropylammonium cations are not involved in the crystal structure. No obvious uptake of N2 and CO2 could be observed for compound 2 due to the shrinkage of the framework and structural transformation. Compound 2 undergoes single-crystal to single-crystal transformation under vacuum, leading to the formation of compound 4, which possesses a two-dimensional layer structure. The photophysical properties of these compounds were also investigated.

elements.content: Quaternary ammonium cations with different sizes were employed for the syntheses of uranyl phosphonates to investigate their influence on structure formation. Quaternary ammonium cation can facilitate the crystallization of uranyl phosphonates. Small ammonium cation can be wrapped in the structure and result in 3D framework structure, while large cation prefers to form 2D intercalation structure. Single-crystal to single-crystal transformation may occur under vacuum. Thermal behaviors and photophysical properties of these uranyl phosphonates were also investigated.

elements.content: Uranium phosphonates have been very attractive in the past decades due to their rich topologies, close relevance to nuclear waste stewardship and separation processes, and interesting properties, including ionic conductivity, ion exchange, gas adsorption, luminescence, magnetism, and so on. Mostly, hexavalent uranium ions are in the form of linear dioxo uranyl dication (OUO)2+. Additional donor atoms, varying from four to six, can only bind with the uranium center at the equatorial positions and form three primary coordination geometries, namely, tetragonal, pentagonal, and hexagonal bipyramids. This kind of structural character strictly restricts the structure extension of the formed uranyl phosphonates. As a result, most of the reported uranyl phosphonates possess two-dimensional layered structures, whereas three-dimensional structures especially permanent porous framework structures are less common. However, three-dimensional uranyl phosphonates are highly desirable because of their interesting properties. For example, one hetero-bimetallic U­(VI)/Co­(II) carboxyphosphonate, Co2[(UO2)6(PO3CH2CO2)3O3­(OH)­(H2O)2]·16H2O, adopts cubic three-dimensional network structure with cavities ∼16 Å in diameter and displays selective gas absorption toward CO2 over N2. Two chiral porous uranium methylenediphosphonates (UC1P2N-1 and KUC1P2–1) display channels ∼1 × 1 nm, which allows them to conduct ion exchange with coordination complexes such as [Co­(en)3]3+.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Uranium phosphonates have been very attractive in the past decades due to their rich topologies, close relevance to nuclear waste stewardship and separation processes, and interesting properties, including ionic conductivity, ion exchange, gas adsorption, luminescence, magnetism, and so on. Mostly, hexavalent uranium ions are in the form of linear dioxo uranyl dication (OUO)2+. Additional donor atoms, varying from four to six, can only bind with the uranium center at the equatorial positions and form three primary coordination geometries, namely, tetragonal, pentagonal, and hexagonal bipyramids. This kind of structural character strictly restricts the structure extension of the formed uranyl phosphonates. As a result, most of the reported uranyl phosphonates possess two-dimensional layered structures, whereas three-dimensional structures especially permanent porous framework structures are less common. However, three-dimensional uranyl phosphonates are highly desirable because of their interesting properties. For example, one hetero-bimetallic U(VI)/Co(II) carboxyphosphonate, Co2[(UO2)6(PO3CH2CO2)3O3(OH)(H2O)2]⋅16H2O, adopts cubic three-dimensional network structure with cavities ~16 Å in diameter and displays selective gas absorption toward CO2 over N2. Two chiral porous uranium methylenediphosphonates (UC1P2N-1 and KUC1P2-1) display channels ~1 × 1 nm, which allows them to conduct ion exchange with coordination complexes such as [Co(en)3]3+.

elements.content: Structure tuning or control is an important issue in the research of uranyl phosphonates, because their properties can be tailored to a targeted one. As one kind of coordination polymers, the structure of uranyl phosphonates can be tuned by altering the synthesis parameters, such as metal/ligand ratio, pH value, reaction temperature, and so on. Besides these parameters, some strategies are also developed. (I) Ligand decoration. In previous years, the phosphonate ligands are mainly monophosphonic acids, such as phenylphosphonic acid and methylphosphonic acid. By decorating the phosphonate ligand with additional coordination group/building blocks (hydroxy, carboxylic, crown ether, and so on), new uranyl phosphonates could be obtained. (II) Incorporation of alkali and transition metal ions. (III) Introduction of ancillary ligand, such as 1,3,5-tri­(1H-imidazol-1-yl)­benzene and 2,2-bipyrimidine. (IV) Organic structure directing (OSD) agents, normally diamines or quaternary ammonium cations.

Besides these parameters, some strategies are also developed. (I) Ligand decoration. In previous years, the phosphonate ligands are mainly monophosphonic acids, such as phenylphosphonic acid and methylphosphonic acid. By decorating the phosphonate ligand with additional coordination group/building blocks (hydroxy, carboxylic, crown ether, and so on), new uranyl phosphonates could be obtained. (II) Incorporation of alkali and transition metal ions. (III) Introduction of ancillary ligand, such as 1,3,5-tri(1H-imidazol-1-yl)benzene and 2,2-bipyrimidine. (IV) Organic structure directing (OSD) agents, normally diamines or quaternary ammonium cations.

elements.content: Keeping these in mind, we are interested in the design and synthesis of new three-dimensional uranyl phosphonates. It is very attractive to investigate the effect of these strategies on the dimensionality of uranyl phosphonates. Triphosphonate ligands have been rarely employed for the construction of uranyl phosphonates. In our previous work, a semirigid triphosphonate ligand, benzene-1,3,5-triyltris­(methylene)-triphosphonic acid (H6L), has been employed for the construction of transition-metal phosphonates. It possesses flexible coordination configuration and diverse coordination modes. The three arms on the benzene ring could adopt up–up–down conformation to coordinate with metal centers and extend into higher-dimensional structures. Therefore, it could be a good selection for the construction of higher-dimensional uranyl phosphonates. At the same time, some quaternary ammonium cations have appeared as OSD agents/templates for the structural tuning of uranyl phosphonates. Quaternary ammonium cations, which are in abundance, easily available, and cheap, are ideal OSD agents. However, it is noted that until now there is no systematic investigation on the effect of quaternary ammonium cations on the structure formation of uranyl phosphonates. Therefore, hydrothermal reactions of H6L with uranyl nitrate hexahydrate in the presence of different tetraalkylammonium cations were performed. Herein, we report on the syntheses, structures, and luminescent properties of four new uranyl triphosphonates, [N­(CH4)4]­[UO2(H3L)]­[H2O] (1), [(UO2)1.5(H3L)­(H2O)1.5]­[H2O] (2), [NBu4]­[(UO2)3.5­(H2L)2]­[(H2O)4.5] (3), and [(UO2)1.5(H3L)­(H2O)2.5]­[(H2O)2.5] (4), where H6L = benzene-1,3,5-triyltris­(methylene)­triphosphonic acid.

elements.content: The synthesis of benzene-1,3,5-triyltris­(methylene)­triphosphonic acid (H6L) was reported in our recent work. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 on a Nicolet 6700 FTIR Spectrometer with KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. The variable-temperature XRD measurements were performed on a hot stage with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. Fluorescent analyses of compounds 1–4 were performed on a Fluoromax-4 spectrofluorometer. Caution! Standard precaution should be taken during the handling of uranium-containing materials.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Instruments

The synthesis of benzene-1,3,5-triyltris(methylene)triphosphonic acid (H6L) was reported in our recent work. Elemental analyses were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 on a Nicolet 6700 FTIR Spectrometer with KBr pellets. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. The variable-temperature XRD measurements were performed on a hot stage with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere. Fluorescent analyses of compounds 1-4 were performed on a Fluoromax-4 spectrofluorometer.  Caution! Standard precaution should be taken during the handling of uranium-containing materials.

elements.content: The diffraction intensity data sets of compounds 1–4 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.710 73 Å) at room temperature. SAINT was used for integration of intensity of reflections and scaling. Absorption corrections were performed with the program SADABS. Crystal structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS. Subsequent difference Fourier analyses and least-squares refinement with SHELXL-2013 allowed for the location of the atom positions. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms on the water molecules (except O3w in 2) of 1–4 were located from the difference Fourier map. All hydrogen atoms were refined using a riding model. The crystal of compound 3 was nonmerohedral twin. The twin refinement was performed on the data in HKLF5 format with SHELXL-2013 using TWIN and BASF commands. The BASF factor in the final refinement of 3 gave a value of 0.46. One butyl group (C31, C32, C33, and C34) of the tetrabutylammonium cation and two lattice water (O3w and O4w) in compound 3 were disordered and refined over two positions with site occupancy ratio of 45/55 for the butyl group and 61/39 for the water molecules, respectively. For compound 4, the value of sin­(θmax)/wavelength is less than 0.575 (0.5566), because the crystal is rather small, and there is just no significant intensity at angles greater than 23.3°. Some guest water molecules of compounds 2 and 4 were disordered and could not be modeled. Therefore, their electron density peaks were removed by the SQUEEZE implemented in PLATON. The crystallographic details are summarized in , and additional crystallographic information is available in the .
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Determination

The diffraction intensity data sets of compounds 1-4 were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. SAINT was used for integration of intensity of reflections and scaling. Absorption corrections were performed with the program SADABS. Crystal structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS. Subsequent difference Fourier analyses and least-squares refinement with SHELXL-2013 allowed for the location of the atom positions. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. The hydrogen atoms on the water molecules (except O3w in 2) of 1-4 were located from the difference Fourier map. All hydrogen atoms were refined using a riding model. The crystal of compound 3 was nonmerohedral twin. The twin refinement was performed on the data in HKLF5 format with SHELXL-2013 using TWIN and BASF commands. The BASF factor in the final refinement of 3 gave a value of 0.46. One butyl group (C31, C32, C33, and C34) of the tetrabutylammonium cation and two lattice water (O3w and O4w) in compound 3 were disordered and refined over two positions with site occupancy ratio of 45/55 for the butyl group and 61/39 for the water molecules, respectively. For compound 4, the value of sin(θmax)/wavelength is less than 0.575 (0.5566), because the crystal is rather small, and there is just no significant intensity at angles greater than 23.3°. Some guest water molecules of compounds 2 and 4 were disordered and could not be modeled. Therefore, their electron density peaks were removed by the SQUEEZE implemented in PLATON. The crystallographic details are summarized in , and additional crystallographic information is available in the .

H6L (0.060 g, 1/6 mmol), (UO2)­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0421 g, 1/12 mmol), 0.1 mL of tetramethylammonium hydroxide (N­(CH4)4OH), and two drops of HF (40%) were mixed and stirred in a Teflon-lined autoclave. elements.content: The reaction conditions were investigated for the construction of uranyl triphosphonates. Tiny crystals or powder samples were obtained at temperature higher than 100 °C. Therefore, the temperature was lowered to 80 °C to gain crystals with suitable size and quality and to avoid the decomposition of tetraalkylammonium hydroxide. The addition of HF solution was vital to the syntheses of the compounds, although fluoride ions were not found in the structures. Our experiments indicated that HF could facilitate the crystallization of uranyl phosphonates and tune the pH to a suitable value (∼1.5). In the absence of HF, gel-like products would be formed instead. Compound 4 could also be obtained by outgassing the single crystals of compound 2 at 70 or 100 °C under less than 1 × 10–6 Pa for 3 h.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses of the Compounds

The reaction conditions were investigated for the construction of uranyl triphosphonates. Tiny crystals or powder samples were obtained at temperature higher than 100 °C. Therefore, the temperature was lowered to 80 °C to gain crystals with suitable size and quality and to avoid the decomposition of tetraalkylammonium hydroxide. The addition of HF solution was vital to the syntheses of the compounds, although fluoride ions were not found in the structures. Our experiments indicated that HF could facilitate the crystallization of uranyl phosphonates and tune the pH to a suitable value (~1.5). In the absence of HF, gel-like products would be formed instead. Compound 4 could also be obtained by outgassing the single crystals of compound 2 at 70 or 100 °C under less than 1 × 10-6 Pa for 3 h.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in monoclinic P2­(1)/c space group with four molecules in the unit cell (see ). There are one uranyl (UO2)2+ cation, one tetramethylammonium, one triply deprotonated triphosphonate ligand (H3L)3–, and one lattice water molecule in the asymmetric unit, corresponding to a formula of [NMe4]­[UO2(H3L)]­[H2O] (see ). The uranium ion is seven-coordinated by two uranyl oxygen atoms (O10 and O11) and five phosphonate oxygen atoms, forming a pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometry with the axial positions occupied by the two uranyl oxygen atoms, while the equatorial positions were filled by the phosphonate oxygen atoms. The UO and U–Ophosphonate bonds are found to be in the range of 1.769(6)–1.776(5) and 2.340(5)–2.383(5) Å, respectively, which are all comparable to those of other uranyl phosphonates (see ). The triply deprotonated diphosphonate ligand displays an up–up–down configuration and adopts a pentadentate coordination mode, which can be denoted as μ5:η0:η0:η1:η1:η1:η0:η1:η0:η1 (see d). Neighboring uranyl cations are connected by these triphosphonate ligands into a three-dimensional framework with channels running along a-axis (see ). The water molecules and the tetramethylammonium ions are accommodated in the channels and form O–H···O and C–H···O interactions with the uranyl oxygen atoms and phosphonate oxygen atoms (see ). The distance between neighboring benzene rings of triphosphonate ligands (center to center) is ∼5.217(3) Å, indicating no significant π···π interactions. Besides the O–H···O and C–H···O interactions, C–H···π interactions are also formed between −CH2– group and neighboring benzene rings (H···π distance: 2.800(1) Å, see Figure S5 and Tables S1–S3). From the view of topology, both the uranyl center and triphosphonate ligand act as 5-connected nodes. The complex network of compound 1 can be noted as a (5, 5)-connected 2-nodal net with the Schläfli symbol of (43.65.82)­(47.63) (see b).

The UO and U-Ophosphonate bonds are found to be in the range of 1.769(6)-1.776(5) and 2.340(5)-2.383(5) Å, respectively, which are all comparable to those of other uranyl phosphonates (see ). elements.content: With the changing of tetramethylammonium hydroxide to tetrapropylammonium hydroxide, a new compound was obtained. Compound 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P2­(1)/m with four molecules in the unit cell. The asymmetric unit is composed of two crystallographic independent uranium ions (U1 and U2, U1 is localized at a special position (y = 0.25), one triply deprotonated triphosphonate ligand (H3L)3–, two aqua ligands (O1w is localized at a special position (y = 0.25)), and one lattice water molecule (see ), indicating a formula of [(UO2)1.5(H3L)­(H2O)1.5]­[H2O]. Both U1 and U2 are seven-coordinated by two uranyl oxygen atoms, four phosphonate oxygen atoms, and one aqua ligand, forming pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometries. The UOuranyl and U–Ophosphonate bond lengths are found in the ranges of 1.71(2)–1.738(14) and 2.304(13)–2.355(16) Å, respectively, which are comparable to those of other uranium phosphonates. The U–Owater bond lengths are observed at 2.49(3) Å for U–O1w and 2.534(15) Å for U–O2w, respectively, obviously longer than those of UOuranyl and U–Ophosphonate, indicating weaker interactions. The triply deprotonated triphosphonate ligand adopts a hexadentate coordination mode and can be denoted as μ6:η0:η1:η1:η0:η1:η1:η1:η1:η0, which means each triphosphonate ligand binds six unranyl cations with its six phosphonate oxygen atoms (see e). These triphosphonate ligands link the uranyl cations into a three-dimensional framework structure with channels running along a- and c-directions (see and S6). The channel size is ∼8.652(14) Å × 8.723(1) Å at a-direction and 6.354(6) Å× 12.314(1) Å at c-direction. The total potential solvent area volume is estimated to be 1104.6 Å3, which amounts to 39.0% of the unit-cell volume (2835.4 Å3). The lattice water molecules can be found in the channels along c-direction. Plenty of hydrogen bonds are formed between these water molecules as well as the aqua ligands with the phosphonate oxygen atoms (see , S2, and S3). From the view of topology, each of the uranyl centers acts as 4-connected node, while the triphosphonate ligand acts as a 6-connected node. The complex network of compound 2 can be noted as a (4, 4, 6)-connected 3-nodal net with the Schläfli symbol of (42.84)­(44.62)2(49.66)2.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of Compound 2 

With the changing of tetramethylammonium hydroxide to tetrapropylammonium hydroxide, a new compound was obtained. Compound 2 crystallizes in monoclinic space group P2(1)/m with four molecules in the unit cell. The asymmetric unit is composed of two crystallographic independent uranium ions (U1 and U2, U1 is localized at a special position (y = 0.25), one triply deprotonated triphosphonate ligand (H3L)3-, two aqua ligands (O1w is localized at a special position (y = 0.25)), and one lattice water molecule (see ), indicating a formula of [(UO2)1.5(H3L)(H2O)1.5][H2O]. Both U1 and U2 are seven-coordinated by two uranyl oxygen atoms, four phosphonate oxygen atoms, and one aqua ligand, forming pentagonal bipyramid coordination geometries. The UOuranyl and U-Ophosphonate bond lengths are found in the ranges of 1.71(2)-1.738(14) and 2.304(13)-2.355(16) Å, respectively, which are comparable to those of other uranium phosphonates. The U-Owater bond lengths are observed at 2.49(3) Å for U-O1w and 2.534(15) Å for U-O2w, respectively, obviously longer than those of UOuranyl and U-Ophosphonate, indicating weaker interactions. The triply deprotonated triphosphonate ligand adopts a hexadentate coordination mode and can be denoted as μ6:η0:η1:η1:η0:η1:η1:η1:η1:η0, which means each triphosphonate ligand binds six unranyl cations with its six phosphonate oxygen atoms (see e). These triphosphonate ligands link the uranyl cations into a three-dimensional framework structure with channels running along a- and c-directions (see  and S6). The channel size is ~8.652(14) Å × 8.723(1) Å at a-direction and 6.354(6) Å× 12.314(1) Å at c-direction. The total potential solvent area volume is estimated to be 1104.6 Å3, which amounts to 39.0% of the unit-cell volume (2835.4 Å3). The lattice water molecules can be found in the channels along c-direction. Plenty of hydrogen bonds are formed between these water molecules as well as the aqua ligands with the phosphonate oxygen atoms (see , S2, and S3). From the view of topology, each of the uranyl centers acts as 4-connected node, while the triphosphonate ligand acts as a 6-connected node. The complex network of compound 2 can be noted as a (4, 4, 6)-connected 3-nodal net with the Schläfli symbol of (42.84)(44.62)2(49.66)2.

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅ with two molecules in the unit cell. The asymmetric unit is comprised of four crystallographically independent uranyl cations, two fourfold-deprotonated triphosphonate ligands (H2L)4– and one tetrabutylammonium and five lattice water molecules (see ). Among the four uranium ions, U4 is localized at a special position (0, 0, 0). The formula can be therefore denoted as [NBu4]­[(UO2)3.5­(H2L)2]­[(H2O)4.5]. It is found that the uranium ions are all six-coordinated, forming octahedral coordination geometries with four phosphonate oxygen atoms lying at equatorial positions. The UO and U–Ophosphonate bond lengths are found in the ranges of 1.685(17)–1.753(17) and 2.201(14)–2.341(16) Å (see ), respectively, which are all comparable to those in other uranyl phosphonates. Different from those in compounds 1 and 2, the two triphosphonate ligands in 3 all adopt cisoid coordination configurations. They are fourfold-deprotonated and heptadentate, displaying a coordination mode of μ7:η1:η1:η0:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η0 (see f). The uranyl cations are connected by these triphosphonate ligands into two-dimensional layers in bc-plane containing 10-member rings. The tetrabutylammonium cations are localized between these layers and interact with neighboring phosphonate oxygen atoms, uranyl oxygen atoms, and water molecules. These C–H···O interactions as well as the O–H···O interactions assemble these layers into a three-dimensional supramolecular structure (see and and S1). This kind of structure can be viewed as one kind of intercalation structure, which is usually found in hydrotalcites.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of Compound 3 

Compound 3 crystallizes in triclinic space group P1̅ with two molecules in the unit cell. The asymmetric unit is comprised of four crystallographically independent uranyl cations, two fourfold-deprotonated triphosphonate ligands (H2L)4- and one tetrabutylammonium and five lattice water molecules (see ). Among the four uranium ions, U4 is localized at a special position (0, 0, 0). The formula can be therefore denoted as [NBu4][(UO2)3.5(H2L)2][(H2O)4.5]. It is found that the uranium ions are all six-coordinated, forming octahedral coordination geometries with four phosphonate oxygen atoms lying at equatorial positions. The UO and U-Ophosphonate bond lengths are found in the ranges of 1.685(17)-1.753(17) and 2.201(14)-2.341(16) Å (see ), respectively, which are all comparable to those in other uranyl phosphonates. Different from those in compounds 1 and 2, the two triphosphonate ligands in 3 all adopt cisoid coordination configurations. They are fourfold-deprotonated and heptadentate, displaying a coordination mode of μ7:η1:η1:η0:η1:η1:η1:η1:η1:η0 (see f). The uranyl cations are connected by these triphosphonate ligands into two-dimensional layers in bc-plane containing 10-member rings. The tetrabutylammonium cations are localized between these layers and interact with neighboring phosphonate oxygen atoms, uranyl oxygen atoms, and water molecules. These C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions as well as the O-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions assemble these layers into a three-dimensional supramolecular structure (see  and  and S1). This kind of structure can be viewed as one kind of intercalation structure, which is usually found in hydrotalcites.

elements.content: The outgassing of compound 2 leads to the formation of compound 4, which displays a two-dimensional network structure. The coordination mode of the triphosphonate ligand is different from that of compound 2 but the same as that found in compound 1 (d). One Ophosphonate–U bond around the coordination sphere of U2 is cleaved under vacuum, leading to the coordination mode change of one phosphonate group from bidentate to monodentate (see ). The vacancy of the leaving phosphonate oxygen atom is then filled by one water molecule from the channels during evacuation (a). Therefore, comparing with compound 2, the asymmetric unit of compound 4 contains one more coordinated water and two more crystallographic independent lattice water molecules. But it does not mean that compound 4 is more hydrated than compound 2, because the lattice water molecules in the channels of compound 2 are removed using SQUEEZE due to disorder. The cleavage of the bonding leads to the structure reduction from three-dimensional framework structure to two-dimensional layer structure (see b). Neighboring layers are further assembled by O–H···O and C–H···O interactions into a three-dimensional supramolecular structure with channels running along a- and c-axes (see and Figure S7). The channel size shrinks significantly from 8.652(14) Å × 8.723(1) Å to 7.431(1) Å × 4.684(3) Å at a-direction and from 6.354(6) Å× 12.314(1) Å to 6.526(1) Å × 5.523(0) Å at c-direction. Additionally, the potential solvent area volume decreases from 39.0% in compound 2 to 19.1% in compound 4.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Description of Compound 4 

The outgassing of compound 2 leads to the formation of compound 4, which displays a two-dimensional network structure. The coordination mode of the triphosphonate ligand is different from that of compound 2 but the same as that found in compound 1 (d). One Ophosphonate-U bond around the coordination sphere of U2 is cleaved under vacuum, leading to the coordination mode change of one phosphonate group from bidentate to monodentate (see ). The vacancy of the leaving phosphonate oxygen atom is then filled by one water molecule from the channels during evacuation (a). Therefore, comparing with compound 2, the asymmetric unit of compound 4 contains one more coordinated water and two more crystallographic independent lattice water molecules. But it does not mean that compound 4 is more hydrated than compound 2, because the lattice water molecules in the channels of compound 2 are removed using SQUEEZE due to disorder. The cleavage of the bonding leads to the structure reduction from three-dimensional framework structure to two-dimensional layer structure (see b). Neighboring layers are further assembled by O-H⋅⋅⋅O and C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions into a three-dimensional supramolecular structure with channels running along a- and c-axes (see  and Figure S7). The channel size shrinks significantly from 8.652(14) Å × 8.723(1) Å to 7.431(1) Å × 4.684(3) Å at a-direction and from 6.354(6) Å× 12.314(1) Å to 6.526(1) Å × 5.523(0) Å at c-direction. Additionally, the potential solvent area volume decreases from 39.0% in compound 2 to 19.1% in compound 4.

Two-dimensional layer structure (b) and three-dimensional supramolecular packing structure (c) of compound 4 viewing along [1 0 1] axis. The -CPO3 tetrahedrons and UO7 pentagonal bipyramid polyhedrons are shaded in purple and yellow, respectively. Hydrogen atoms and water molecules in (c) are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: To investigate the single-crystal to single-crystal transformation behavior, the crystals of compound 2 were treated under vacuum in the sample container of IGA at different temperatures (25, 70, and 100 °C), which all resulted in the formation of compound 4. This suggested that evacuation played a decisive role in the structural transformation from 2 to 4. To verify this, variable-temperature XRD measurements were performed by heating the crystals of compound 2 on the hot stage of Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer in the temperature range from 25 to 150 °C (Figure S8). It was found that the characteristic diffraction peaks of compound 2 got broader and weaker with the increasing of temperature, but no evidence could be observed for the formation of compound 4. Therefore, most probably the framework structure of compound 2 shrank significantly under vacuum and caused the breaking of one Ophosphonate–U bond, leading to the structural transformation. To examine the reversibility of the structural transformation, the single crystals of compound 4 were exposed to water vapor at room temperature in a closed small vial for one week. Disappointingly, the structural transformation was irreversible (see Figure S9).
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal to Single-Crystal Transformation

To investigate the single-crystal to single-crystal transformation behavior, the crystals of compound 2 were treated under vacuum in the sample container of IGA at different temperatures (25, 70, and 100 °C), which all resulted in the formation of compound 4. This suggested that evacuation played a decisive role in the structural transformation from 2 to 4. To verify this, variable-temperature XRD measurements were performed by heating the crystals of compound 2 on the hot stage of Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer in the temperature range from 25 to 150 °C (Figure S8). It was found that the characteristic diffraction peaks of compound 2 got broader and weaker with the increasing of temperature, but no evidence could be observed for the formation of compound 4. Therefore, most probably the framework structure of compound 2 shrank significantly under vacuum and caused the breaking of one Ophosphonate-U bond, leading to the structural transformation. To examine the reversibility of the structural transformation, the single crystals of compound 4 were exposed to water vapor at room temperature in a closed small vial for one week. Disappointingly, the structural transformation was irreversible (see Figure S9).

elements.content: To investigate the influence of quaternary ammonium cations, different quaternary ammonium cations (Me4N+, Et4N+, Pr4N+, and Bu4N+) were tested for the synthesis of uranyl phosphonates. It was found that quaternary ammonium cation had a major impact on the structure formation of uranyl phosphonates. Small quaternary ammonium cation could be enwrapped in the voids and facilitate the formation of anionic three-dimensional framework structure. Tetramethylammonium falls in this scope, serving as structure directing agent as observed in compound 1. When tetraethylammonium was used, unidentified polycrystalline powder was obtained. Neutral three-dimensional framework structure could be formed with the employment of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide. With the further increase of organic cation size, intercalation structure, assembled from anionic uranyl phosphonate layers and inter layer tetraalkylammonium cations, was obtained as observed in compound 3. A survey of the literature also reveals that small quaternary ammonium cations, including Me4N+, Et4N+, Et2Me2N+, and Me3EtN+, can be enwrapped in the channels and form three-dimensional framework structures but become difficult for larger organic cations.
elements.clean_text:
The Effect of Quaternary Ammonium Cation on the Structure Formation

To investigate the influence of quaternary ammonium cations, different quaternary ammonium cations (Me4N+, Et4N+, Pr4N+, and Bu4N+) were tested for the synthesis of uranyl phosphonates. It was found that quaternary ammonium cation had a major impact on the structure formation of uranyl phosphonates. Small quaternary ammonium cation could be enwrapped in the voids and facilitate the formation of anionic three-dimensional framework structure. Tetramethylammonium falls in this scope, serving as structure directing agent as observed in compound 1. When tetraethylammonium was used, unidentified polycrystalline powder was obtained. Neutral three-dimensional framework structure could be formed with the employment of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide. With the further increase of organic cation size, intercalation structure, assembled from anionic uranyl phosphonate layers and inter layer tetraalkylammonium cations, was obtained as observed in compound 3. A survey of the literature also reveals that small quaternary ammonium cations, including Me4N+, Et4N+, Et2Me2N+, and Me3EtN+, can be enwrapped in the channels and form three-dimensional framework structures but become difficult for larger organic cations.

elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analyses were performed to investigate the thermal stabilities of compounds 1–4 (see ). There are two stages of obvious weight losses for compound 1 in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first one, ∼2.6%, occurred in the temperature range of 90–150 °C and could be ascribed to the loss of lattice water molecules (theoretic: 2.5%). The second weight loss (10.0%) could be found in the temperature range of 340–450 °C, matching well with the theoretic value (10.3%) of one [NMe4] moiety in each formula. Therefore, the second weight loss should be caused by the removal of [NMe4] species. It started to decompose upon further heating. For compound 2, it started to lose weight at ∼40 °C, indicating the existence of apt-to-lose guest molecules in the channels. At 200 °C, a weight loss of ∼14.1% was observed, corresponding to the removal of ∼6.5 water molecules in each formula (theoretic: 14.5%). In combination with the results of single-crystal structural and elemental analyses, it could be speculated that there are two crystallographically independent coordination water and five lattice water molecules in each formula, namely, [(UO2)1.5(H3L)­(H2O)1.5]­[(H2O)5]. With the increase of temperature, the framework started to collapse. In the case of compound 3, its TGA curve is similar to that of compound 1. The first weight loss (4.2%) could be observed in the temperature range of 85–120 °C, which could be assigned to the removal of lattice water molecules (theoretic: 4.1%). The second weight loss (10.0%) occurred in the temperature range of 330–400 °C and could be ascribed to the removal of [NBu4] species (theoretic: 12.2%). The thermal behavior of compound 4 is similar to that of compound 2. At 130 °C, a weight loss of ∼12.9% was observed, suggesting that there are six water molecules in each formula (theoretic: 12.7%). When heated further, the sample started to decompose slowly.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stabilities

Thermal gravimetric analyses were performed to investigate the thermal stabilities of compounds 1-4 (see ). There are two stages of obvious weight losses for compound 1 in the temperature range from 25 to 800 °C. The first one, ~2.6%, occurred in the temperature range of 90-150 °C and could be ascribed to the loss of lattice water molecules (theoretic: 2.5%). The second weight loss (10.0%) could be found in the temperature range of 340-450 °C, matching well with the theoretic value (10.3%) of one [NMe4] moiety in each formula. Therefore, the second weight loss should be caused by the removal of [NMe4] species. It started to decompose upon further heating. For compound 2, it started to lose weight at ~40 °C, indicating the existence of apt-to-lose guest molecules in the channels. At 200 °C, a weight loss of ~14.1% was observed, corresponding to the removal of ~6.5 water molecules in each formula (theoretic: 14.5%). In combination with the results of single-crystal structural and elemental analyses, it could be speculated that there are two crystallographically independent coordination water and five lattice water molecules in each formula, namely, [(UO2)1.5(H3L)(H2O)1.5][(H2O)5]. With the increase of temperature, the framework started to collapse. In the case of compound 3, its TGA curve is similar to that of compound 1. The first weight loss (4.2%) could be observed in the temperature range of 85-120 °C, which could be assigned to the removal of lattice water molecules (theoretic: 4.1%). The second weight loss (10.0%) occurred in the temperature range of 330-400 °C and could be ascribed to the removal of [NBu4] species (theoretic: 12.2%). The thermal behavior of compound 4 is similar to that of compound 2. At 130 °C, a weight loss of ~12.9% was observed, suggesting that there are six water molecules in each formula (theoretic: 12.7%). When heated further, the sample started to decompose slowly.

elements.content: The emission spectra of compounds 1–4 were recorded under excitation at 365 nm at room temperature (see ). As we know, uranium-containing compounds usually display characteristic green emissions, arisen from the electronic and vibronic transitions of S11–S00 and S10–S0v (ν = 0–4). However, for compounds 1–4, the expected fine peaks around 540 nm were not observed but rather a series of bands in the range of 450–510 nm and a weak broad band around 600 nm. The peaks in the range of 450–510 nm could be attributed to the emissions of phosphonate ligand because of their resemblance to the spectrum of H6L. The broad band around 600 nm could be ascribed to the vibronic transitions of uranyl species but appeared to be quenched by nonradiative decay.
elements.clean_text:
Photophysical Properties

The emission spectra of compounds 1-4 were recorded under excitation at 365 nm at room temperature (see ). As we know, uranium-containing compounds usually display characteristic green emissions, arisen from the electronic and vibronic transitions of S11-S00 and S10-S0v (ν = 0-4). However, for compounds 1-4, the expected fine peaks around 540 nm were not observed but rather a series of bands in the range of 450-510 nm and a weak broad band around 600 nm. The peaks in the range of 450-510 nm could be attributed to the emissions of phosphonate ligand because of their resemblance to the spectrum of H6L. The broad band around 600 nm could be ascribed to the vibronic transitions of uranyl species but appeared to be quenched by nonradiative decay.

elements.content: Four new uranyl triphosphonates have been obtained from a triphosphonate ligand by tuning the size of quaternary ammonium cations. It is found that quaternary ammonium cations could facilitate the crystallization of uranyl phosphonates and have a major influence on the structure formation of uranyl phosphonates. Small quaternary ammonium cations could serve as counterions and structure directing agents, resulting in the formation of three-dimensional anionic framework structures. With the increase of size, three-dimensional neutral framework structure or two-dimensional intercalation structure could be obtained instead, since it becomes difficult for large quaternary ammonium cations to be enwrapped in channels. This work demonstrates that uranyl phosphonates with targeted structures could be assembled by judicious selection and combination of phosphonate ligands and tetraalkylammonium cations. Single-crystal to single-crystal transformation could be triggered for flexible uranyl phosphoantes by exposing to vacuum.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Four new uranyl triphosphonates have been obtained from a triphosphonate ligand by tuning the size of quaternary ammonium cations. It is found that quaternary ammonium cations could facilitate the crystallization of uranyl phosphonates and have a major influence on the structure formation of uranyl phosphonates. Small quaternary ammonium cations could serve as counterions and structure directing agents, resulting in the formation of three-dimensional anionic framework structures. With the increase of size, three-dimensional neutral framework structure or two-dimensional intercalation structure could be obtained instead, since it becomes difficult for large quaternary ammonium cations to be enwrapped in channels. This work demonstrates that uranyl phosphonates with targeted structures could be assembled by judicious selection and combination of phosphonate ligands and tetraalkylammonium cations. Single-crystal to single-crystal transformation could be triggered for flexible uranyl phosphoantes by exposing to vacuum.

H6L (0.060 g, 1/6 mmol), (UO2)­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0421 g, 1/12 mmol), 0.1 mL of tetramethylammonium hydroxide (N­(CH4)4OH), and two drops of HF (40%) were mixed and stirred in a Teflon-lined autoclave. Afterward, it was sealed and heated at 80 °C for 3 d and allowed to cool to room temperature in a time period of 12 h. Yellow block crystals could be obtained with satisfying yield (0.049 g, 82% based on metal source). Anal. Calcd (%) for C13H26NO12P3U (719.29): C 21.71, H 3.64, N 1.95%; found: C 21.66, H 3.78 N 2.01%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3585.4 (m), 3331.3 (m), 2914.3 (w), 1635.6 (w), 1600.2 (w), 1487.4 (m), 1462.2 (w), 1410.5 (w), 1233.5 (m), 1149.5 (s), 1122.4 (s), 1054.3 (s), 1024.9 (s), 1005.4 (s), 937.9 (m), 909.3 (s), 877.8 (w), 820.4 (w), 761.3 (w), 712.9 (w), 694.5 (w), 597.1 (w), 524.9 (w), 496.6 (w), 451.0 (w).

Syntheses of Compounds <bold>2</bold> and <bold>3</bold>

Compounds [(UO2)1.5(H3L)­(H2O)1.5]­[H2O] (2) and [NBu4]­[(UO2)3.5(H2L)2]­[(H2O)4.5] (3) were synthesized at 80 °C with the same method used for compound 1 except the replacement of tetramethylammonium hydroxide with tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (NPr4OH) and tetrabutylammonium hydroxide (NBu4OH), respectively. Pure phases of compounds 2 and 3 could be obtained with satisfying yields. For compound 2: Anal. Calcd (%) for C9H17O14.5P3U1.5 (807.18): C 13.39, H 2.12; found: C 13.44, H 2.28%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3440.0 (b, s), 2919.8 (m), 2386.1 (b, w), 1605.3 (m), 1457.9 (w), 1410.5 (w), 1248.0 (m), 1123.4 (s), 1058.0 (s), 971.1 (m), 923.1 (s), 832.1 (w), 754.4 (w), 715.9 (w), 642.6 (w), 519.2 (m), 435.0 (w). For compound 3: Anal. Calcd (%) for C34H67NO29.5P6U3.5 (1980.81): C 20.62, H 3.41, N 0.71%; found: C 20.69, H 3.48, N 0.72%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3526.8 (b, m), 2959.0 (m), 2398.2 (b, w), 1605.9 (m), 1487.9 (w), 1458.1 (w), 1410.1 (w), 1220.6 (m), 1200.0 (m), 1101.2 (s), 1049.7 (s), 923.5 (s), 844.8 (w), 757.8 (w), 723.5 (w), 634.5 (w), 516.8 (w), 439.9 (w).

Synthesis of Compound <bold>4</bold>

The single crystals of compound 2 were outgassed at room temperature under ultrahigh vacuum (<1 × 10–6 Pa) for 12 h using an Intelligent Gravimetric Analyzer (IGA 001, Hiden Isochema Ltd., Warrington, UK) and resulted in the formation of compound 4. Anal. Calcd (%) for 4·H2O (870.23): C 12.55, H 2.60; found: C 12.59, H 2.67%. IR­(KBr, cm–1): 3471.1 (b, s), 1634.9 (m), 1458.9 (w), 1407.9 (w), 1242.2 (m), 1146.8 (m), 1113.5 (s), 1064.2 (s), 919.9 (s), 832.1 (w), 753.3 (w), 713.7 (w), 521.7 (w), 500.5 (w), 465.6 (w), 439.1 (w).
